title: Before 1 January 2022, will a commercial, open to the public, ride-hailing service that uses autonomous vehicles without back-up drivers nor remote operators be launched in the People's Republic of China?
preds: Give it five years, then we talk.
Not happening this year, for sure!
No - technology is not yet reliable or safe enough to operate without human activity intervention
given the logical format includes remote backup drivers, it is clear that this will likely never happen.
Technology is not mature enough yet. Chinese gov will be careful before rolling out to avoid backlashes, esp. as it is currently reining in big tech operators.

There's multiple companies testing autonomous cars in China currently, with billions at their disposal. However, the chances of them being operational with a fleet large enough to handle public demand, before the start of 2022, is incredibly small. The earliest that public testing could go live would be around March 2022.
I3 months is a short timeline, however Baidu reported level 4 on the road in taxi service with "backup" driver.      I am going to up my prediction to 5%, but I think that March is the date.

1-Economy slow down in China due to Delta variant spread.
2-Shortage of chips supply.
I cannot find any evidence that anyone is promising this service before 2022 Winter Olympics and I do not think that anyone is willing to put their reputation on the line with a half baked product.
After the AV in US stopped at a orange full moon, I think we’re not there yet!

I am with Colorkarma on this. The AutoX RoboTaxi trials IMHO show better promise than Tesla and are being trialled with no drivers in much more messy parts of China than Palo Alto, and the videos seem to indicate a much more resilient decision making process than the Tesla FSD betas despite the larger Tesla datasets. I would be happy to commit to a much higher number if the date was further away, however, as they have enabled remote monitor technology, why would they turn it off?  Just to meet this question? I imagine / hope all future publicly available ride hailing services will include a remote monitoring and control process that would allow a stuck vehicle to get out of a situation that, for whatever reason, requires a human to intervene and approve a route that looks unsafe to the computer.
Aversion to risk, what big tech company will put their head up to do this and see it get chopped off?

sources:
https://www.econotimes.com/Baidu-to-make-thousands-of-robotaxis-for-a-driverless-service-in-China-1611110
"
CNBC mentioned that while Baidu’s plans for the robotaxis have been laid out, it is not clear when the actual production is set to begin. There is no exact detail about the period that Baidu is aiming to deploy the first batch of the driverless EVs." ANSWER:
It seems that technology is a little behind time, Tesla , which has an advantage is still developing and solving issues regarding autonomous vehicles.
China is behind and AI technologies have not proven safe enough.. China has traffic issues.

AutoX is planning to overtake Baudi - and in Shenzen Provicne there is more opportunity to manage
https://vnexplorer.net/robotaxi-race-heats-up-in-china-autox-unveils-superior-upgrade-2-a2021249509.html
Doubt that the technology would be ready by then.

underestimated Tesla's lead. I think only Tesla would be able to do it and as non-Chinese company, it will not be allowed to be first. Also, for fear of negative PR, no trials without remote operators will happen due to accidents then being able to be blamed on individual supervisors rather than incompletely developed driving system.

Baidu launches Apollo Go robotaxis in Beijing in the area of Shougang Park before a wider rollout in time for the Olympics.
A number of developers are currently testing driverless, Level 4 taxis in geofenced areas, but a wider debut remains far on the horizon.
Uber and Lyft have dropped autonomous research units entirely, selling them to cut costs, which indicates how close they think robotaxis really are to wider deployment.
https://www.autoweek.com/news/technology/a36354137/beijing-olympics-robotaxi-china/

Germany is said to be developing its own too, 'beating China and the US.' But it's really hard to see one without remote control capabilities or remote monitoring; heck, it doesn't make sense to have just remote monitoring if you cannot remote control in case something happens. In the following article, the author writes, "Under the law, a technical command center would be tasked with overseeing the fleet remotely should any trouble ensue." If Germany has such a law in place, why would China not follow similarly both as a logical reason but also as a proxy. Still, anything can happen in China. With something so autonomous, I expect there to be in place regulations that would cause this to resolve NO. PS: Assumption only. https://fortune.com/2021/05/28/germany-automobile-legalize-robotaxi-autonomous-vehicle/
The technology is not ready yet

Not willing to pay for technology and they are going with their own developement, I doubt that whatever they have copied is too anticuated already. You need better process to keep leapoing forward with tech and the tests.

Baidu has started running ten driverless taxis in Beijing, but they have "safety monitors" in the front passenger seat in case things start to go badly.  Presumably this doesn't count, but it may up the odds on something happening by next year.  Coming up gradually and reluctantly, because I'm probably wrong about the time frame.

With the crowd on this one. I'd like to take a moment to acknowledge a recent news report that Baidu is launching a service that fits the criteria for this question to resolve as YES; however, there is a caveat because apparently there will still be remote control in this case, which would not count. On the other hand, there are a BUNCH of other potential companies, pilot programs, and government support on this topic in this country that it's worth mentioning that anything is still possible. "Because they won’t have backup drivers, the robotaxis will be connected to a 5G-based remote control system designed to ensure the rides are safe"
https://www.caixinglobal.com/2021-04-30/baidu-to-roll-out-driverless-robotaxis-in-beijing-in-may-101704549.html @jleibowich @bobrown @Kavoca
Eventually yes, but 2022 is too soon

So this article reinforces my view that the Chinese will be flexible on rules and want this to happen https://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Business-Spotlight/China-guides-its-self-driving-startups-into-the-fast-lane That said, no real idea how to convert that view into a probability, especially given the date is arbitrary. Time has gone by though without any clear progress, plus skepticism from Crowd. Dropping to 29%
Time is ready and China will demonstrate technology
Not a lot of updates.  Trying to think of other ways to look at this, and coming up blank.  Going to stick with my 65% after reading some more on Waymo and the opening of their China branch.

What China is good at is not new advanced technology, such as autonomous driving, what China is good at is low cost commercialization. So the second best selling EV in China in 2020 is Wuling Hongguang, mini EV, a 4500$ one. And this one is very likely to outperform Tesla's Model 3 in China in 2021, even in the world. 
https://www.bbc.com/news/business-56178802 At the same time, US is tightening the AI transfer to China, because of the huge value in military use, making it more difficult for China to acquire or develop autonomous driving by itself.
https://www.nscai.gov/2021-final-report/
I just don't see it feasible that emergency monitoring and remote control not being part of such projects.

I find it fascinating that all of these companies are working together to get this done.  Motional, the joint venture between Hyundai and Aptiv; Pony.ai and Toyota; Blackberry and Baidu.  Granted, there are still a lot of government regulations that are going to be needed to approve and give the final blessing on true "driverless" cars for commercial ride-hailing.  The news of the Lyft venture in Las Vegas in the last week has been an interesting development (albeit with safety drivers and engineers still in the car, for now).
https://apnews.com/article/technology-driverless-cars-joint-ventures-las-vegas-nevada-99e57b67cd6685b33bb19efa7d5ff63e
https://www.pymnts.com/news/investment-tracker/2021/autonomous-vehicle-tech-pony-ai-raises-100-million/
https://techcrunch.com/2021/01/25/blackberry-and-baidu-deepen-autonomous-connected-car-partnership/

Reducing % chance substantially because of this article quoting WeRide CEO which seems to suggest the timelines are significantly extended
https://werideai.medium.com/weride-ceo-tony-han-committed-to-long-term-strategy-in-autonomous-driving-7037eb838cd3 "When our technologies meet the industry standards, we will apply for commercialization. I’m sure that the appropriate policy support will be in place when the right time comes. However, I cannot offer an exact timeline at this moment. Technological progress and policy legislations are rather unpredictable. What we are focusing on right now is to aggressively advance our technology while promoting commercialization."
Dropping significantly on the Feb. 2 note. Reading some of the comments and articles posted here it sounds like remote emergency control is still mandatory for all of these companies.

We have autonomous vehicles with no drivers or back-ups, but that can't take passengers.
And we have autonomous vehicles that can do rideshare, but have back-up drivers.
I wonder if they could dual-purpose an Appolo-Cop or New Species vehicle as a ride-sharing service.  WeRide just received China's first license for an AV ride-hailing service.  I think they're closer than we imagine.
https://www.traffictechnologytoday.com/news/mobility-as-a-service/baidu-introduces-worlds-first-multi-modal-autonomous-driving-maas-platform-in-guangzhou.html
https://www.caixinglobal.com/2021-02-11/weride-wins-chinas-first-license-for-self-driving-ride-hailing-service-101663190.html
The 2/2 clarification makes this one unlikely to resolve to yes over any time frame.
Down 10, this year would be pretty short time frame for AV.

Looks like I botched my last forecast. Thank you to @jleibowich for commenting and making me aware of my mistake.  Going to revert to my old projection but double the possibility as there seems to be movement based on the AutoX advances

Though Autonomous Vehicles are quite close to becoming a reality around the world, the risks and issues of the softwares for them to be considered 100% reliable will still take from 5 to 20 years to be put into circulation.
The chance a autonomous vehicle with no back-up driver being put into circulation is low and, if it does, it will probably be taken back until legislation makes autonomous vehicles the norm and human drivers prohibited which can take anywhere from 20 to 50 years.
Will  China have their own geostationary satellites that will not be screwed with by Alien beings?

I changed my mind. Like with many other questions on GJO, again with conjunction fallacy in mind. With so many requirements to YES and the majority of questions resolving NO, this is not a convincing event to occur. For now, I am also going to trust our local China forecasters on this one. However, I am aware that experts in a particular domain can be more wrong than the non-expert. I think my current probability forecast sits between the expert judgement and crowd judgement, which tend to be overconfident.

Coin-flip chance of tech avail but no approval, CF chance no tech at all meets criteria, CF chance there is a delay (say planning fallacy or any other kind of delay), CF chance approved for YES resolution, slightly likely chance tech is developed and approved but not for public use with payment, in respect to previous analyses. Side note: Some other questions I do not agree with decreasing probabilities as time passes, as the probability of certain events are constant no matter how close to resolution time it is. Sometimes there is even a cluster of higher probabilities around certain time periods. However, I think this is one where as time ticks, the chances go down.

China now has six companies that are approved to test driverless (no "in-car" driver) cars in both PRC and the United States.  However, all of the companies are still required to have "remote operators" in case of emergency. 
https://www.theverge.com/2021/1/27/22252944/baidu-driverless-cars-test-permit-california-dmv

"Baidu Apollo Go robotaxi service is now operational in Beijing, Changsha, and Cangzhou, and has carried over 210,000 passengers.The company’s plan is to expand its robotaxi service to roughly 30 cities over the next three years."
https://roboticsandautomationnews.com/2021/01/28/baidu-apollo-receives-driverless-vehicle-test-permit-in-california/40012/

Hattip to @Fueled_by_Gummybears for finding the article bellow about a draft law allowing testing on highways.  Any legal movement is a promising sign that the Chinese government (the main obstacle to an autonomous ride hailing service) is trying to move toward AVs. However, the draft law is not yet approved and shows no movement on the legal issues mentioned in my last forecast.  https://www.intelligenttransport.com/transport-news/114787/china-autonomous-vehicle-laws/
https://www.scmp.com/tech/policy/article/3117735/china-allow-driverless-car-tests-highways-putting-it-same-lane-us

New legislation by Beijing to allow for testing on busier roads means the government is likely more open about the idea of autonomous vehicles than I originally thought.  That being said, after reading about the difference in bus service on a controlled road compared to a taxi service on a highway without a remote operator, I am lowering the outcome.  Although I still believe this will be likely somewhere in the PRC on a small scale.
https://www.intelligenttransport.com/transport-news/114787/china-autonomous-vehicle-laws/

I think I let my initial overenthisiasm get the better of me, so updating. Tricky one as it feels very difficult to baseline. My gut feel is this is not that difficult to resolve as a yes, and China may be willing to be more accommodative at least on a small scale than other countries to get the “first”.
Hattip @xuehuisz for rationale that got me to change my forecast. Is it possible in 2021, maybe. Is it likely in 2021 less so. Going first brings acclaim unless it goes bad.
Not yet prepared for that. More time required.

I think it is very unlikely, reasons are:
1) China's hidden unemployment rate is pretty high, this is a very controversial topic, and no accurate data can be obtained, but judging from  number of  package delivering guys all around big cities in China, (Meituan 美团，Shunfeng 顺丰 etc）, and armies of Didi (滴滴打车）drivers  who can be booked via smartphone apps, there are millions of people who can only find simple jobs such as above. Mostly young males.
Even if the technology is ready, government would be very cautious of approving it.
2) So far, there are no level 5 autonomous driving cars on the market. Car makers had made lots of over optimistic predictions, but so far, no one.
3)The driving conditions in China is even more complex in US, packaging delivery guys riding electric bicycles never follow the traffic rule, and they move so fast, without noise (one advantage or disadvantage of electric bicycles), Old people never follow the traffic rule. Many drivers don't follow the rule strictly, for example, at least half drivers in Shenzhen (the city I live in) don't turn on direction lights before they turn.  And many would drive faster than allowed or driving on emergency lanes, as long as there is no camera.
China intends to dominate global (EM) smart-cities

Bumping up because it is unlikely in the first half of the year, reports say they'll need six months of real world testing, probably outside of China itself, before they'll be opened to the Chinese public.

Commercial Autonomous ride-hailing services, as described in the question, are highly unlikely due to the lack of laws and regulations currently in place to govern the legal issues that will arise. The current regulations (The 2018 National Road Testing Guidelines)  covering autonomous vehicles(AVs) only govern the testing of said vehicles, not commercial use. The guidelines require a test driver to be able to intervene at any moment. The timetable for developing new regulations to govern AVs beyond testing are estimated by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology to not be completed until 2025. 
“...MIIT seeks to promulgate at least 30 key national standards by 2020, that will support AVs with driver assistance functions and low-level automated driving functions, and to develop a more comprehensive system with more than 100 national standards by 2025 geared to support high-level automated driving.”
https://www.insidetechlaw.com/autonomous-vehicles/05_china The regulations needed are wide-ranging and without precedent as described by a February 2020 joint strategy released by 11 central Chinese government departments.   
“The Strategy stresses the importance of improving laws and standards for intelligent vehicles. The priority areas include the identification of “robot driver”, liability, cybersecurity and data management in relation to intelligent vehicles and also ethical research, clarification of legal rights, obligations, responsibilities of stakeholders and road testing”
https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=0b02f4ca-8c4f-4b66-aa4c-1ce5d6dfb97a  The creation of and use of detailed maps of Chinese streets, essential for AV's success,  is seen as a high-level national security threat. 
https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=0b02f4ca-8c4f-4b66-aa4c-1ce5d6dfb97a In recent months Chinese regulators have been cracking down on big tech for monopolistic behavior. This climate makes it unlikely that AV companies are willing to attempt to push regulators by beginning commercial operations without approval. Especially, seeing as the main company under fire is Alibaba, owner of AutoX, the AV company with the most developed AVs. 
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/13/china-faces-the-challenge-of-keeping-big-tech-in-check.ht Finally, there has been a lack of posturing/claims of soon to arrive commercial fully autonomous taxis. This kind of hype building is to be expected if one of the companies were nearing commercial rollout, but I found no such claims in my research.  Explanation of the 5% possibility. 
In early December 2020 AutoX secured approval in the city of Shenzhen for a “completely autonomous fleet,” the 25 cars do not have human back-up drivers or remote operators.
However, the article qualified, “AutoX’s completely driverless robotaxis are not open to the general public yet. They are only available to employees and private guests, such as media, business partners, investors and auto-makers, according to CEO Jianxiong Xiao”. 
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/04/fully-driverless-cars-are-being-tested-in-china-for-the-first-time.html The fact that this company avoided the requirements under the 2018 National Road Testing Guidelines cited above shows there may be wiggle room for companies to begin commercial services.  I don't believe it is necessary to answer the question but I wonder if anyone has insight from within the industry on whether or not any Chinese or International companies have developed their systems to be safe enough for the roads without driver intervention?
eHang will probably launch such a service for airborne eVTOLs by the end of 2021
I think deep learning alone without general ai  is unlikely to achieve full inner city self driving. However a more limited version (highways only, very specific areas) may qualify for this question.

Hattip @BrianL for the reference succinctly defining the possibilities for a program in Beijing to allow robo-taxis at the 2022 Winter Olympics (04 FEB - 20 FEB 2022). "With around 13 companies including Baidu and NIO getting permits to test their vehicles. Beijing has become the front runner for the future. It would be no surprise when the city is one of the first in the country to have a fully functional fleet of Robotaxis and this may come as soon as the 2022 Winter Olympics."
Perhaps the technology is not yet ready, but that will not stop people from trying. The publicity is priceless unless there is an accident.
It will be approved in China before that in the USA

Autonomous driving is an open ended complex task which is impossible without remote operators to do: situations rise where the car just don't know what to do. The task is so complex that in two years such a service won't be open to public with remote operators either.

The announcement is seen as a step to have Robotaxis available for the 2022 Winter Olympics hosted in the city. Applicants must test their vehicles in closed areas for 5,000 kilometers before they are allowed onto public roads. In addition, a minimum of 1 million RMB (around 143,000 dollars) insurance must be purchased for each volunteer in the testing if the company would like to apply for a permit to transport customers. Which is unavoidable if companies would like to test drive on public roads as commercial activities are not allowed for the testing period, meaning they must have volunteers for test driving, thus must have insurance.  ‘.. the implementation of Robo-taxi services, several barriers were identified, such as technological barriers (fully automated vehicles not yet on the road), regulatory barriers (vehicle-licensing standards), and cost (with affordability being a key issue.’ https://www.hindawi.com/journals/jat/2020/8877499/ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotaxi
https://www.axiomsource.net/blog/Beijing-announces-Robotaxis-China-s-big-move-for-the-future

Reducing my forecast because I realize that a lot of the conditions that exist in Arizona for Google to do their right sharing service probably do not exist in China. Google is probably relying heavily on having roads that are well mapped out by Google maps.

An excellent summary article offered by @Fueled_by_Gummybears
https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/03/tech/autox-robotaxi-china-intl-hnk/index.html
Suggests that it may be near a time when the technology is ready, but the regulation and the public must also be ready.
It's not clear how or when all the conditions are in place for this to take place. In 2023 the answer might be YES, in 2021, I am skeptical and don't believe a commercial service open to all will be launched, but perhaps, service limited to company employees may be put in place.
Weather and traffic conditions in Beijing are not the same as in San Jose or Shenzhen. 
8 is a lucky number in China, seems appropriate for this question at this time. 364 days to go.

It sounds like they're very close. But one of the main competitors, AutoX, which just got approval for autonomous vehicles with no backup driver in Shenzen, says in the linked article they intend to obtain permission to expand to regular passengers in the next 2 to 3 years. Other companies currently have to have backup drivers. I'm not sure why the long timeframe. Waymo has recently started offering taxi service in the US in autonomous vehicles with no backup driver. Maybe Waymo is just that much farther ahead? Putting this at 35% right now on the chance that another company comes in and gets approval, the reporting was off on AutoX, or AutoX moves at a faster pace than anticipated. https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/03/tech/autox-robotaxi-china-intl-hnk/index.html
I think even a 1 in 6 chance is a little generous, even for China. The tech is within reach, but there are a lot of hurdles to be resolved.

I think the odds are good that Baidu, AutoX and the other competitors in this zone will feel confident that their technologies are ready within 2021, and regulatory issues will be addressed (or close to it). However, for most of 2021 I think the data will be significantly more valuable than any potential service fees they could gather from their R&D fleets, so they won't bother to charge for the rides. (The infrastructure for charging customers might be more expensive than the revenue earned.) Once a manufacturer thinks it is ready to launch a commercial ride-hailing service, they will need to move this from an R&D project to a commercial enterprise. That will probably involve creating a new company to manage the commercial enterprise, or else partnering with someone with similar expertise, and training the personnel required to maintain the fleet. These will need to be separate from the R&D personnel, or else no further progress will be made in R&D. I could easily imagine it taking another six months to sort out those details. My forecast is further reduced by the odds that one of the following things might happen: 1) An economic downturn causes a delay in the process; 2) it might turn out to be easier to run a pilot enterprise in a Southeast Asian city outside of China, where accidents would not cause as much political backlash.
They can do anything.  Did you see the way they built 1000s bed hospitals during Covid crisis.
Road safety concerns and insurance liability issues will not be resolved so soon.
Elon Maks is pushing with the fully self-driving car. China would like to be first and it is ready to reduce safety requirements in its own country.
Reduced from 45% to 35% May see public service available in limited & controlled area (shopping district, golf course etc), but unlikely to hit all the criteria including payment
Unlikely because autonomous vehicle technology combined with all of the other necessary software may not be ready yet.
1. Technology is not far enough advanced.
China will not allow unemployment in their country to increase.  They will try/test it out locally but will deploy the technology to the rest of the World

So we’ve got Waymo (Alphabet) that has taxis in San Jose.
Baidu has service (with safety drivers) in Shanghai.
AutoX (Ali Baba) that has auto taxi service in Shenzhen and San Jose.
According to the CNN article, this is the first time they’ve fully removed the driver. I’m thinking at least one more year until its good enough to fully remove the driver AND the remote operator, and become a paying service. Looks like many are free right now just to get people used to the idea.
https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/03/tech/autox-robotaxi-china-intl-hnk/index.html
Although there is an outside shot for this hitting to market within 12 months, it is more likely too short a timeframe to have moved from pilot projects to commercial
Due to lack of sensors and solutions for ethical problems autonomous Driving in cities will need 10+ years to be realised.
Given that Waymo has already rolled out something like this (on an extremely small scale) and there are multiple Chinese players involved, I expect to see a nominal Chinese equivalent crop up soon.

China is eager to demonstrate its leadership in technology and innovation. With other autonomous vehicle actors stepping aside, this would be a feather in their cap. This does not necessarily mean that they will be successful for long.
Will look into that, but human life is less of a concern in some places, so why not

The technology is there. The real question is the amount of testing to be done, and other sort of regulations that the Chinese government will want to add to it. It would be a mistake to use public data published in China about their progress, so honestly one can only guess.
Maybe in limited capacity in Shanghai, but likelihood of even that is low.  Infrastructure with autonomous vehicles is highly underrated.
China will want to be a first as a matter of prestige.
Possible that we see a service like this launched in a bespoke environment, perhaps with geofencing, given this would lower the technological threshold

Part of the global leadership that China is exercising is to project itself with innovation, and they have all ready to do this project.  So expect a parade of AVs if only for show in a limited environment.

The articles make this sounds imminent, but one article I read (https://edition.cnn.com/2020/12/03/tech/autox-robotaxi-china-intl-hnk/index.html) says that the company hopes to have paying customers "in two to three years" and I think the press frequently over-hypes how imminent driverless car advances are. Plus there seem to be endless delays for driverless cars, which keep having dates promised for widespread use which don't happen. Missing one more year seems a low bar. On the other hand, there is no minimum number of cars for this to be met. Even a trial of 5 cars would do it. So I think there's a significant chance below 50%, it's an outside chance not a fleeting one.

Hard to try to put numbers on this, but the articles linked suggest that this is more of a regulatory than tech issue (at least in the sense that they already have the tech, just only available to certain people; it may well be a bad idea that goes wrong when implemented). It feels like the Chinese government will be keen to do this for the headlines/victory and approving it for a small city is probably not seen as a big risk to the Chinese government overall. Going with 85% e.g. pretty likely.
It's still early in the development of the technology and its application in real world traffic for the Chinese government to allow robot-taxis without back-up drivers or remote operators.
Updated with ongoing coverage of this area
It will be part of an integrated public transit approach
There is one currently operating in Arizona run by Google. The technology is in existence. It seems perfectly feasible that Google or someone else will implement this within the next year in China.

The quoted material indicates that the taxis are already in use with back up drivers to take over in an emergency. So the technology is there.  In order to make this profitable, the driver must be eliminated. Compound this following CoVid and you have a situation where people are more comfortable without another person in the car with them and China’s greater trust in technology, and you have a perfect opening.  The only factor I see in the question is the date.  Before or after ...

Depends on the strict definitions being employed. Does this have to be citywide on public streets with mixed usage? Or can it be a made-for-PR limited launch somewhere like a business park or major shopping area or an entertainment complex? If the streets are places which also have bicycles, motorbikes & trucks, then very low likelihood. If it's a more controlled environment then (essentially) automated golf-carts aren't a big deal and just look like the equivalent of unmanned rail systems.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apolong https://apollo.auto/robotaxi/index.html
https://apollo.auto/minibus/index.html Currently L4 AD, probably in L5 beta status soon and tested.
Very close call with respect to the time frame, but it's likely that they will want to premiere the service on a limited scale, and to benefit from additional real use case data.
